td.h2: COVID-19 Communication to Families and Staff (updated 4/17/2020)
td.p: First and foremost, we sincerely hope this correspondence finds you and your families all safe and in good health as we continue our fight against COVID-19. Although these are diverse times, it is important we look for the learning during this experience; hence how will this help us improve our future work together, in what ways can we better partner in educating our youth, and what systems or structures can we change to increase our efficacy as a team? These are all positive byproducts of the COVID-19 disruption to our past normal which will, ultimately, help us in defining a new, future normal for us. Thank you for all your doing during this time.

On a more formal note, this morning Governor Reynolds issued a proclamation ordering all schools to be closed for the remainder of the school year (see video link below). With this news, Iowa has taken another incremental step toward public safety, and Saydel CSD will do our part to aid in keeping our communities safe and healthy. Saydel CSD will extend our closure, including all activities, events, Community Education, and facility rentals, through the end of the school year. Please note, we will continue to offer the Voluntary Educational Enrichment Opportunities (VEEO) during this time and will communicate plans for summer learner expectations as well as how we will resume school in the Fall. These communications will take all Iowa Department of Public Health COVID-19 mitigation guidance, on how we can safely resume educational services, into consideration in our plans.

Next, we understand that this is a difficult time for families, and we want you to know educators are working hard to provide learning activities for your kids and to your families through the Voluntary Educational Enrichment Opportunity (VEEO) model the Iowa Department of Education has outlined for schools. We will continue to provide resources, materials, and offer our services to you as we plan and prepare forward. Please feel free to reach out to teachers and principals if you need anything and we will do our best to accommodate. Otherwise, know that the resources shared by teachers along with others will be available to you 24-7 on a special section of our website: https://www.saydel.k12.ia.us/students/closure-resources-for-students.cfm.

On another note, the Saydel Foods and Nutrition Services will continue to serve meals. For more information, please call our Foods and Nutrition Services Office at 515.264.0866 or visit the following Saydel CSD Website link: https://www.saydel.k12.ia.us/district/school-closure-meals.cfm

Additionally, if you and/or anyone in your family are experiencing heightened states of concern and growing anxiety that many of us may be feeling, we would like to remind you of an important resource. All Saydel CSD students and their families have access to the Student Assistance Program (SAP) through Employee & Family Resources (EFR). You do not need a referral. You can call the number directly, let them know you are a Saydel School family, and request assistance. The assessment is at no cost; services include referral and short-term counseling for students and their family members. For telephone support and scheduling, please call: (515) 244-6090. District employees are also welcome to contact EFR for services and support.

As we close today, know that this has been hard on all of us, so please allow yourselves grace as you navigate through this global hardship. Also know we are in this together and we have never been more proud of our community, and how we have pulled together than we are right now. Our partnership is more important now than ever-THANK YOU!
Todd A. Martin, Saydel CSD Superintendent

td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. To help prevent the spread of Coronavirus, or COVID-19, in Iowa and the United States that has occurred in other countries such as Italy and China, Saydel Community Schools is requesting that families keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if a student has these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact the school to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website: cdc.gov/coronavirus. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease.

p.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in Saydel Community Schools.

td.p: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses, Iowa Department of Public Health, and Polk County Health Department, as well as review updates from the CDC.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

td.h2: WHAT CAN I DO TO PREVENT THE SPREAD OF THE VIRUS?

ul.li: Wash hands with soap and water frequently, for at least 20 seconds
Use alcohol-based sanitizers when soap and water are not available
Use disposable tissues when coughing and sneezing; dispose of carefully and promptly
If tissues are not available, direct your cough or sneeze into the crook of your arm/sleeve
Avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unwashed hands
Clean and disinfect “high-touch” objects and surfaces
Stay home when you are sick, and remain home until fever-free for 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing medication
Avoid close contact with anyone who has cold or flu-like symptoms
Maintain healthy habits that support your immune system

td.h2: WHAT IS SAYDEL CSD DOING TO REDUCE THE SPREAD OF VIRUSES?

p.br: Saydel CSD is closely monitoring COVID-19 and is in contact with the Centers for Disease Control, Iowa Department of Public Health and Polk County Department of Health to follow all recommended protocols and procedures. Trained staff routinely are monitoring individuals who exhibit fever, cough, and shortness of breath and are following appropriate assessment and monitoring protocols for students and staff who report feeling ill. The district is encouraging all students and staff to follow all preventative health measures, which include frequent hand washing, covering coughs, and staying home when sick.

td.p: Saydel CSD is continuing to follow its standard procedure for routine cleaning and disinfection of schools, with special emphasis placed on disinfection of door handles and other frequently touched areas, as suggested by local and state health officials and the Iowa Department of Education. Custodial teams also are making sure all schools and buildings are properly stocked with needed supplies, including soap and paper towels. Additionally, Facilities, Maintenance, and Operations cleaning agents are hospital grade disinfectants. Transportation Services also is preparing to enhance daily bus-cleaning efforts with the addition of interior sanitization, a practice often implemented by the department during cold and flu season. Plans call for buses to be sanitized with disinfectants after routes are completed each day, as a precautionary measure.

The district is continuing to monitor the situation to ensure all precautionary measures are in alignment with current guidance from local, state, and national health officials and in the best interest of students and staff.

This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic and the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13 on all travel from Europe to the U.S.
We will continue to monitor the situation and be in contact with area school districts and health departments about whether to close any schools.

Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country with a Level 3 travel health notice, please contact the student building before returning to school. The CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days. Read more at cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers.

We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students’ safety first. If you have any questions, reach out to the Saydel district office or your student's building.
